awd_titl_txt: Chemomechanics in the Solvent-Assisted Recycling of Engineering Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
Many engineering composites are troublesome to recycle because the polymers used in these materials are bonded together permanently. Currently, the disposal of composite wastes mainly relies on the landfills or incineration, which lead to significant environmental and health burdens. A new green, sustainable recycling method was recently developed to address this problem. It uses a bond-exchange reaction between a solvent and the composite to decompose the polymer material at a mild temperature and reclaim clean fibers. The decomposed products can be used to fabricate new composites with near identical material and mechanical properties for the same applications. However, due to the nascent development of this recycling technique, existing studies are limited to the proof of concept demonstrations. This award supports fundamental studies to uncover the relationships between waste material properties, processing conditions, recycling speed, and final mechanical properties of recycled thermosets and composites. The provided scientific knowledge will pave the road for the immediate applications of this innovative recycling method and significantly ease the environmental and health concerns associated with the traditional waste disposal methods. This research will also impact large-scale applications in other industries involving polymer decomposition and recycling, such as removable encapsulation of electronics, non-destructive surface coatings, controlled drug delivery, membrane science, and microlithography. Additionally, the project will provide opportunities to educate and train graduate and undergraduate students with a focus on underrepresented students in science, technology, engineering, and math.

The research objectives will be realized using an integrated experimental - theoretical - computational approach at multiple length scales: In the microscale, constitutive chemomechanics relations will be defined to link the molecular-level bond-exchange reactions to the evolution of stress field, network structure, and mechanical properties of thermosets during the recycling. In the mesoscale, the constitutive relations will be incorporated into a computational model to study the influences of the fiber-polymer interface on the recycling performance of a composite lamina. In the macroscale, an efficient reduced-order computational model will be developed to guide the selection of solvent and processing conditions to recycle composite structures with the well-controlled geometry and mechanical properties. The chemomechanics theory defined in this award will be used to address three fundamental questions that are mostly concerned in the composite recycling industry: (i) how fast can the composites be recycled, (ii) what is the lowest recycling cost, and (iii) how to improve the mechanical properties of recycled products?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: University of Colorado at Denver-Downtown Campus

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project focuses on conducting fundamental studies of an innovative and sustainable recycling method designed for thermosets and their fiber-reinforced polymer composites. By heating them in a suitable alcohol-based solvent, the crosslinking networks can be fully depolymerized to recover clean fibers. The resulting depolymerized solution can then be re-polymerized to create a composite with mechanical properties nearly identical to the original material (see Figure 1).

In the initial phase of this project, we developed constitutive chemomechanics theories for solvent-assisted thermoset recycling (Figure 2). These theories are essentially multiscale, linking the microscale transportation of reactive species and chemical reaction kinetics to the macroscale recycling behaviors, including depolymerization speed and the mechanical properties of recycled polymers. Our experimental-theoretical-computational approach is versatile and can be applied to the solvent-assisted recycling of polymers with various chemical compositions and network structures. By combining it with multi-physical experimental characterizations, we were able to reveal the complex interactions between polymer networks and solvent molecules, influenced by various material and process parameters, such as temperature, catalyst content, solvent choice, polymer crosslinking density, and more. Our studies provide clear material-process-property relationships for the recycling process.

Next, we integrated the constitutive theories with finite-element computational simulations to study the recycling processes of composites embedded with fibers. The developed computational tools and user subroutines closely match the experimental data in terms of depolymerization and repolymerization speeds, as well as the mechanical properties of recycled laminates. Specifically, we discovered how fiber content and arrangements affect the transportation of solvent, matrix curing, and the stress relaxation induced by volume shrinkage around the fibers during composite recycling. A significant outcome of our studies is the revelation of distinct domains where recycling behaviors are dominated by either temperature and solvent or the high residual stress around the carbon fibers. This study substantially enhances our understanding of the recycling process for fiber composites, which will greatly benefit their immediate engineering applications.

Our exploration of the recycling process of fiber composites extends to other relevant fields, enabling innovative and sustainable manufacturing methods for composites, self-healing and repair mechanisms, and recyclable 3D printing of thermosets and their composites (see Figure 3). In these applications, the depolymerization and recycling of the thermoset matrix under organic solvents plays a crucial role in determining the quality and mechanical properties of the final composite products. The theory and computational models we provide offer valuable guidance in selecting optimal process conditions and simultaneously enhance our understanding of this new technology. These theories and computational tools will assist polymer scientists and manufacturers in applying these strategies and will challenge the conventional views of thermosets and composite processing.

To date, this project has generated 15 peer reviewed journal papers, 2 papers currently under review, and 1 issued US patent.

Broader impact:

The research conducted in this project offers a fundamental understanding of a novel, environmentally friendly recycling method with broad-reaching impacts in engineering applications. The solvent-assisted recycling method for thermosets and their composites significantly addresses environmental and economic concerns associated with traditional disposal techniques, such as landfills, incineration, and harsh chemicals. It also meets the growing demand for composite recycling. Furthermore, this research has implications for large-scale applications in various industries involving polymer decomposition or re-polymerization, such as removable encapsulation of electronics, non-destructive surface coatings, controlled drug delivery, membrane science, and microlithography.

This project has created valuable research and training opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students at CU Denver. It has provided full or partial support for two Ph.D. students who have successfully defended their degrees, as well as ongoing support for two Ph.D. students currently in their studies. Additionally, the project offers training opportunities and support to multiple underrepresented undergraduate students, a master's student, and a Grade-twelve high school student in the PI's lab, enabling them to conduct research on relevant topics.

In addition to the publication of research papers, the PIs and their group members have shared their findings at various conferences, including the annual conferences of the Society of Engineering Science and ASME IMECE, which are among the most prestigious conferences in the field.

The project also includes outreach workshops at local high schools to disseminate the research. During these classroom presentations, the PI and their students introduce the concepts of Composite Advanced Manufacturing and Recycling Techniques, covering current recycling approaches in the US and the recently emerged solvent-assisted recycling methods. They also explain the recycling mechanisms and highlight the environmental and economic benefits of composite recycling.

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2023
Modified by: Kai Yu
